content.description: This is another one I have taken many new climbers on. Its more fun than it looks!Follow the crack to the top. Use the left dihedral if you need to.
content.location: Broken crack that faces the river located immediately left around the corner from the the obvious ramp.

content.description: Face climb to the right of Gail's Folly.
Start around the corner from Cemetery Gates climb face up to good ledge about half-way. Crux is overhanging face on top half of route.
content.location: Faces up-stream on far west end of wall.

content.description: Climb the arete left of Shimmer. The route comes at you from both sides. Sustained and fun.
content.protection: Set top rope on the face of the wall next to Shimmer & Glimmer.

content.description: Face climb good edges on consistently challenging rock just left of Gail's Folly, but right of Glimmer on Harkor Tower. Provides a moderate Niner between those two climbs. Stay out of the crack, or you're climbing Gail's Folly, 5.6.
content.protection: TR with slings from Large Tree or crack system on top of Tower; this requires scaling the back-side up 12-15 feet from the wooden staircase's middle 'landing.'
content.location: Just left of Gail's Folly, but right of Glimmer on Harkor Tower. Central face-climb on left side of center split on Harkor Tower.

content.description: Around the Corner to the left of Glimmer. DO NOT USE CORNER.
content.protection: Trees and Rock for Top Rope Anchors

content.description: I've taken many people who are new to climbing over to this route at the end of their climbing day. It's not world class but is fun for beginners. Climb the awkward left-leaning ramp to the dihedral that is usually full of ferns. For the last 10ft, exit the dihedral to the left or go straight up the hand crack for more fun.
content.protection: Standard rack (up to 4 if you have it) Watch for loose/rotten rock
content.location: Obvious ramp just around the corner from the bottom of the stairs.

content.description: Gain the ledge just like in Cemetery Gates.  Shuffle left and shoot up the thin broken crack left of Cemetery Gates.
content.protection: Possible on lead, though gear would be thin up top.
content.location: Same start as Cemetery Gates(5.10)  A few feet left of Cemetery Gates after the ledge 15 feet up

content.description: Climb directly up the face to the right of the chimney. DO NOT USE LEFT CORNER Palisades classic face climb.
Large crack with a large loose stone.
Climb the west facing wall inside the chimney to the large crack at the top.
content.protection: Trees and Rock for great top rope anchors

content.description: Starting on the corner, dance your way up the arete and through the bulge.  Continue your journey up the corner to the top.
content.location: Located on the arete just right of Cemetery Gates

content.description: Cemetery Gates is on the far right side of Harkor Tower. The climb starts at the base of a large tree. Climb up 15 feet on the large flake/pillar which should be slung carefully to prevent zippering the next two placements. Awkwardly stand on top of the pillar and get a small nut up high and right. Climb the crux section on small edges, and place a second small nut to protect a few more small edges before reaching jugs and an obvious widening crack.

Palisades State Park is on the southern edge of the Coteau des Prairies, a series of glacial deposits that extend north and south for nearly 200 miles in eastern South Dakota. A thin layer of debris was deposited by glaciers atop the quartzite. Beds of dark red pipestone can be found between the layers. 

  This is one of the few areas in the nation where pipestone is found. The mineral was considered sacred by American Indians and depressions still remain where it was once quarried.  

  For millions of years, Split Rock Creek cut deep gorges through Palisades State Park. Geologists estimate the Sioux quartzite spires are 1.2 billion years old.  

  Four hiking trails twist and turn through these beautiful Sioux quartzite formations. The cliffs and formations are also used by organized climbing groups to practice their scaling and rappelling techniques. Bolting is not allowed on the quartzite formations. Please contact the park before you head out for other climbing regulations.
